fullText:
Democracy Dies in DarknessReview by  Naveen KumarNEW YORK — Real life can be stranger and more thrilling than fiction, particularly when the line between the two dissolves at spitting distance. When rousing protesters stood and approached the stage at Thursday’s performance of “An Enemy of the People” at Circle in the Square Theatre, the demonstration seemed less like a disruption than an otherwise stolid revival delivering an invigorating coup.

showScoreExcerpt: "Climate activists disrupting Jeremy Strong was the best part of the play"

llmScore.reasoning: [ensemble-unanimous] | All 3 models agree: Pan | Claude: This statement directly implies that an external disruption was better than the actual performance, indicating the critic found the play itself severely lacking. | GPT-4o: The quote suggests that the most memorable or enjoyable aspect of the play was an external disruption, implying the play itself did not offer much value or entertainment. | Gemini: The critic stating that the disruption was the best part of the play indicates a very negative view of the actual production.
